abstract: World Health Organization's declaration that glyphosate, active ingredient in Monsanto weed killer Roundup, likely causes cancer in humans shows how scientific data can be interpreted differently by different organizations; agency's research was in part based on study used by Environmental Protection Agency to reverse itself and approve use of Roundup, six years after using same study to suggest that it may cause cancer.
lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency gave the maker of Roundup a thumbs up in 1991, but a World Health Organization group now says the active ingredient “probably” causes cancer.

headline.main: Weed Killer, Long Cleared, Is Doubted
headline.print_headline: Weed Killer, Long Cleared, Is Doubted

snippet: The Environmental Protection Agency gave the maker of Roundup a thumbs up in 1991, but a World Health Organization group now says the active ingredient “probably” causes cancer.
